***A foreword to the tutorial:*** *This is a MATLAB tutorial that I prepared for the students of METU EEE department, specifically for the course EE306 and EE230. I wrote it assuming the students had some basic MATLAB syntax knowledge and built on that to introduce some best-practices in MATLAB regarding clean & efficient coding, report writing, and an introduction to probabilistic computations in MATLAB. I decided to share it here in full open source-spirit. Naturally, everyone is welcome to use it and download it provided they give due credit.* 

*A warning: Only the last frame of the animations and the current values of the interactive controls are shown here, so if you want to run the animations (and look at my triangle go weee) and play with the interactive controls, you can download the original Live Script from [here](/files/LivingWithMATLAB_extended_OgulCanYurdakul.mlx). The below tutorial is an HTML export from this very document (with minor tweaks).*

MATLAB in General<br>
</span></a><a href = "#H_AA5B2020"><span>II. Coding and Report Writing in MATLAB<br>

</span></a><span>    </span><a href = "#H_B919E053"><span>II.3. Efficient &amp; Debugged Code<br>
</span></a><span>    </span><a href = "#H_8D8D650D"><span>II.4. Presentable Results<br>
</span></a><a href = "#H_6539F7E4"><span>III. MATLAB for Probability Computations<br>
</span></a><span>    </span><a href = "#H_A6A82728"><span>III.1. Functions for Probability<br>
</span></a><span>    </span><a href = "#H_5B26B0B2"><span>III.2. Handling Continuous Quantities<br>
</span></a><span>    </span><a href = "#H_7CA6769B"><span>III.3. Monte Carlo<br>
</span></a><a href = "#H_FC3B3653"><span>Appendix A. Function Declarations<br>
</span></a><span>    </span><a href = "#H_6BF67EF3"><span>A.1. iid. Bernoulli Sampler</span></a></div></div><h2  class = 'S5' id = 'H_FDC90014' ><span>I. MATLAB in General</span></h2><div  class = 'S1'><span></span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Brushing up on your MATLAB syntax.</span><span style=' font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;'> </span><span>Before going into this tutorial, you should know the basics of coding in MATLAB, as it builds on that knowledge further on. Some of these basics are the following:</span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span>Creating, manipulating, indexing and slicing vectors (1D arrays) &amp; matrices (2D arrays)</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>Control and loop commands: </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>if</span><span>, </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>while</span><span>, </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>for</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>Writing custom functions</span></li></ul><div  class = 'S6'><span>One resource provided by MATLAB is </span><a href = "https://www.mathworks.com/learn/tutorials/matlab-onramp.html"><span>MATLAB Onramp</span></a><span>, which is an introductory course on MATLAB covering the basics. The additional benefit of MATLAB Onramp is that it also gives a completion certificate, which is always nice to have (especially if you are hunting for internships).</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Beyond syntax.</span><span> Coding is much more than just knowing the syntax. Simply knowing how certain basic commands are written and executed in the MATLAB syntax is essential, but it is up to you as the coder to figure out how a verbally or mathematically specified problem should be coded. Some basic questions could be the following:</span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span>What data structures do I need? Will regular arrays suffice, or do I need cell arrays, structs, etc.? Should I create my own, composite data structures out of the existing basic ones?</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>What is the basic flow of the algorithm I am supposed to implement? What are the basic checks and computations that need to be performed?</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>How does the problem decompose itself into smaller subproblems? What should be their appropriate inputs and outputs? (more </span><a href = "#M_B9473929"><span>in Section II.1</span></a><span>)</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>What are my computational constraints? How much computational power can I use, and how long is the program allowed to run?</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>How should a user interact with my code? Does it need a Graphical User Interface (GUI) or can I make the user efficiently interact with the code via the command line?</span></li></ul><div  class = 'S6'><span>These are just some of the basics that come to my mind right now, and I have no doubt the list above is not exhaustive. But my point is this: Learning how to think about and answer these questions requires </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>practice.</span><span> You don't read your way into it.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>One cool tool for practicing your MATLAB coding skills can be </span><a href = "https://www.mathworks.com/matlabcentral/cody/"><span>MATLAB Cody</span></a><span>, a gamified problem solving service provided by MATLAB. It also has problem groups specific to different topics, such as combinatorics or vector computations (not to be confused with vectorizing your code). It could be fun, go check it out.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Finding help.</span><span> The very first thing you should know about any programming language/environment is where to find help. MATLAB is a very strong language in that front, due to its popularity. It is extensively documented, with in-line help texts and documentation pages offline. The fastest way to get to them is through the command window:</span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>help &lt;function name&gt;</span><span> brings the help text accompanying the function. This should your first attempt at figuring out how a function works.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>doc &lt;function name&gt;</span><span> opens the documentation of your function in a pop-up window, which is the same documentation you will find online (i.e. no need for opening up your browser). I recommend you go this way usually after trying </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>help</span><span> first, as the documentation is much longer and extensive, although much more user-friendly and clickable.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>lookfor &lt;keyword&gt;</span><span> is usually unknown, with good reason. It searchs for the </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>keyword</span><span> in the whole documentation/help texts of MATLAB, and will give you any match it gets, although I assume the search can be refined. (Check the help/documentation of </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>lookfor</span><span>!) It is like a Google Search but in MATLAB, and will give you tons of functions. </span></li></ul><div  class = 'S6'><span>Aside from these function helps, if you just don't know how to do/code something in MATLAB, do the first thing that I am sure came to your mind:</span></div><div  class = 'S1'><span>Google Search "</span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>&lt;thing&gt;</span><span> in matlab"</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>The MATLAB/Mathworks Community is immense, and somebody has most likely asked the same or a very similar question before. Don't bother reinventing the wheel (but also don't plagiarise!).</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Relatively new facilities of MATLAB. </span><span>As it is a widely-used programming language, MATLAB is constantly updated with new and useful facilities. I highly recommend you always use the latest available version (MATLAB will let you know when they're out), which is currently 2022a, because they not only improve the GUI or whatever but also they syntax. The three latest improvements I find useful are the following</span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' text-decoration: underline;'>MATLAB syntax now has the </span><span style=' text-decoration: underline; font-family: monospace;'>switch</span><span style=' text-decoration: underline;'>-</span><span style=' text-decoration: underline; font-family: monospace;'>case</span><span style=' text-decoration: underline;'> structure</span><span> you most likely encountered in other languages, which saves you from using a bunch of </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>if</span><span> statements.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' text-decoration: underline;'>Function variables can now be declared in the usual </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>variableName=value</span><span style=' text-decoration: underline;'> format</span><span> when calling a function, instead of the previous name-value pair syntax of </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>'variableName', value</span><span>.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' text-decoration: underline;'>The MATLAB GUI now supports autocomplete</span><span>, which helps greatly for quick coding.</span></li></ul><div  class = 'S6'><span>After registering with your METU mail and the school's MATLAB license on the Mathworks website, you will get access to the following tools:</span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><a href = "https://www.mathworks.com/products/matlab-drive.html"><span>MATLAB Drive</span></a><span> is the cloud storage service of MATLAB. There is no obligation to store MATLAB-related files exclusively, but as the capacity is somewhat limited that is how you should proceed. </span></li><li  class = 'S8'><a href = "https://www.mathworks.com/products/matlab-mobile.html"><span>MATLAB Mobile</span></a><span> is the mobile application of MATLAB (iOS &amp; Android), and I find it mostly useful for its command line rather than scripting actual code. It integrates well with MATLAB Drive, and so you can run your code stored there on your mobile. It can also store data from the sensors on your phone, which can also come in handy in various projects.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><a href = "https://matlab.mathworks.com"><span>MATLAB Online</span></a><span> is the way to go if you don't want to download many GBs of MATLAB to your computer, it is like Google Colab but for MATLAB. You can write codes &amp; Live Scripts in MATLAB and run them, but will be limited by your Internet connection. MATLAB Online also integrates automatically with MATLAB Drive.</span></li></ul><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>MATLAB is a very high-level language. </span><span>As a last warning in general about MATLAB, I should mention that MATLAB is a very high-level language, meaning it may not always do what you think it does. You should always check the documentation of the functions you are using. The code you write may seem to be working, i.e. it may compile and run and produce some output, but it may not work they way you want it to, simply because a function does its taks in an unexpected way under the hood.</span></div><h2  class = 'S5' id = 'H_AA5B2020' ><span>II. Coding and Report Writing in MATLAB</span></h2><div  class = 'S1'><span></span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>The quick summary of this whole section is </span></div><div  class = 'S1'><span style=' font-style: italic;'>Write </span><span style=' font-style: italic; text-decoration: underline;'>working</span><span style=' font-style: italic;'> code that you would </span><span style=' font-style: italic; text-decoration: underline;'>want to read and understand</span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>You can take this as me asking for a "personal favor" from you on behalf of all the TAs and instructors, or anybody who might have/want to read your codes and reports. Keeping this motto in mind will not only help your future graders immensely, but also help </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>you</span><span> write better working/looking code and think more coherently when doing so. </span></div><h3  class = 'S9' id = 'H_F61D0BAD' ><span>II.1. Clean &amp; Legible Code</span></h3><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Starting Clean &amp; Continuing So.</span><span> How you start writing your code is usually how you finish it: Start messy and you will end up with terrible looking code. Start clean and it will remain clean. So let's start clean, by cleaning everything in the way.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S10'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >clearvars; close </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">all</span><span >; clc;</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>This may look redundant, as it looks like you are cleaning what is already clean. But when you run your code consecutively (as one often does) without such a quick clean up, you risk carrying over the variables from your previous run. At best, your code will throw an error and you will notice what is wrong. At worst, your code will run when it isn't supposed to: You may have adjusted a variable here and there to make it work along the way, and so the code appears to work when you run it the second time.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>MATLAB is insensitive to white space, unlike some other languages out there. This is a great benefit: You can add white space anywhere to make your code more legible. Consider the following, very simplistic examples: Which one is better? This one:</span></div><div class = 'preformatted-matlab' style = 'margin: 10px 3px 10px 55px; padding: 10px 10px 10px 5px; '><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >x=-1:0.01:1;</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >N=5;</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >figure</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">for </span><span >i=1:N</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >subplot(51i)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >plot(x,sin(i*x))</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">end</span></span></div></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>or, this one:</span></div><div class = 'preformatted-matlab' style = 'margin: 10px 3px 10px 55px; padding: 10px 10px 10px 5px; '><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >x = -1:0.01:1;</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >N = 5;</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >figure</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">for </span><span >i = 1:N</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >   subplot(51i)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >   plot(x, sin(i * x))</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">end</span></span></div></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>The second one takes much more space, but isn't it much easier on the eyes? They both do the exact same computation in the exact same manner, so the don't lose anything in terms of functionality, but gains a ton on the legibility front. This helps you make sense of your code, and more importantly spot any error much more quickly.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>Secondly: Name your variables meaningfully. MATLAB absolutely does not care what you name your variables as long as it is </span><a href = "https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/matlab_prog/variable-names.html"><span>valid</span></a><span>, and it allows for a wide range of variable names as it is also case sensitive. It may be gibberish or a line from Shakespeare, they are all the same in the eye of the compiler. So, why not name your variables in a more descriptive manner, so that you understand what they are more quickly? For example, if you are computing the mean of your random samples, don't opt for an onverly simplistic </span></div><div class = 'preformatted-matlab' style = 'margin: 10px 3px 10px 55px; padding: 10px 10px 10px 5px; '><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >m = mean(samples);</span></span></div></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>but instead for</span></div><div class = 'preformatted-matlab' style = 'margin: 10px 3px 10px 55px; padding: 10px 10px 10px 5px; '><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >sampleMean = mean(samples);</span></span></div></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>or for</span></div><div class = 'preformatted-matlab' style = 'margin: 10px 3px 10px 55px; padding: 10px 10px 10px 5px; '><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >sample_mean = mean(samples);</span></span></div></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>The first convention is called the </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>camel case</span><span>, and the second one is the </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>snake case</span><span>. You don't have to choose one or the other either. You can use the underscore to stand for a subscript, too: For example if you have two random variables </span><span texencoding="X_1" style="vertical-align:-6px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="17" height="18.5" /></span><span>and </span><span texencoding="X_2" style="vertical-align:-6px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="17" height="18.5" /></span><span>, naming their sample means as </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>sampleMean_1</span><span> and </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>sampleMean_2</span><span> would make quite a lot of sense. The other extreme would be to make the variable names </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>too explanatory</span><span>, like</span></div><div class = 'preformatted-matlab' style = 'margin: 10px 3px 10px 55px; padding: 10px 10px 10px 5px; '><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >sampleMeanOfTheSamplesFromTheRandomVariableX = mean(samples);</span></span></div></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>It is an exaggerated example, but it serves to show how much is too much. In short, keep your variable names short but descriptive to quickly understand what they are further on in the code.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Helping Yourself.</span><span> As you continue your education or work, your codes will only get more complicated and long, so it is important you know how to help your future. Your code makes a ton of sense as you are writing it in the moment, but trust me, it will look like absolute nonsense after some time. If you don't explain to yourself</span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span>what variable contains what, </span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>how your functions work, </span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>what quantitiy is being computed in one run of the for loop,</span></li></ul><div  class = 'S6'><span>etc., you will have to put an unnecessary amount of work in the future. For example, if I compute a series of quantities that depend on one another in a for loop for a range of parameters, some quick commenting like</span></div><div class = 'preformatted-matlab' style = 'margin: 10px 3px 10px 55px; padding: 10px 10px 10px 5px; '><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">for </span><span >p = params</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Compute quantity 1</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Compute quantity 2 using the quantity 1</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Check if quantity 2 meets a certain condition</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Store the result of check</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">end</span></span></div></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>helps </span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span>you have a better mental image of what is actually happening in the loop, hence allowing you to code and debug faster, and helps </span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>other readers of your code make sense of it much quicker. </span></li></ul><div  class = 'S6'><span>If you are having further troubles with your code, you might try some documented </span><a href = "https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Rubber_duck_debugging"><span>rubber duck debugging</span></a><span> by explaining what happens at each line to a virtual (or real) rubber duck.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>You will also often write functions of your own to help your computation, the utility of which I will mention in the following subsection. Adding help texts to your functions will help you understand what they do at a quick glance, without opening and reading the function definition all over again. For example, here is the help text of a Bernoulli variable sampler I wrote:</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >help </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">Bernoulli</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsTextElement" uid="B9CA9712" data-testid="output_0" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="textElement eoOutputContent" data-width="1258" data-height="192" data-hashorizontaloverflow="false" style="max-height: 261px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">--- <strong style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">Bernoulli</strong> not found. Showing help for <strong style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">double/bernoulli</strong> instead. ---

  <strong style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">bernoulli</strong> Bernoulli numbers and Bernoulli polynomials.
     Y = <strong style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">bernoulli</strong>(N, X) is the N-th Bernoulli polynomial.
     It is defined as
     <strong style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">bernoulli</strong>(n, x) = limit(diff(t*exp(x*t)/(exp(t) - 1), t, n), t, 0)
     Y = <strong style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">bernoulli</strong>(N) is the N-th Bernoulli number.
     It is defined as
     <strong style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">bernoulli</strong>(n) = bernoulli(n, 0).
     See also euler.

    Documentation for double/bernoulli
    Other functions named bernoulli</div></div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>It is quick and effective. Helps a ton.</span></div><div  class = 'S6' id = 'M_B9473929' ><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Modularity &amp; Sectioning.</span><span> The problems that you will have to solve via coding in any environment will usually be immense, and will only get bigger in time. Tackling the whole problem at once will almost always be very difficult, if not altogether impossible. Therefore, you should be able to </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>separate the problem into smaller, sub-problems.</span><span> This has two main advantages:</span></div><ol  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span>The big and scary problems will turn into much more manageable, smaller problems. Less adrenalin, more control.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>More importantly, because you will be going one sub-problem at a time, it will be easier to identify which of your sub-solutions is malfunctioning when there is something wrong with the overall code. On the positive side, as you progress upwards from smaller problems to the bigger ones, you will be relying safely on the well-working of the smaller components of bigger programs, allowing you to not think about everything at ones but work in abstractions.</span></li></ol><div  class = 'S6'><span>A great way to modularize your code is using the sectioning utility of MATLAB. In </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>.m </span><span>files and </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>.mlx</span><span> files alike, MATLAB allows you to separate your code into sections which can be run individually. This way, when you just want to change one small bit at the end, you don't have to run eeeverything from the beginning, but only the last section (it is especially useful when prettifying figures). In a </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>.m</span><span> file, this works as follows:</span></div><div class = 'preformatted-matlab' style = 'margin: 10px 3px 10px 55px; padding: 10px 10px 10px 5px; '><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">%% Section 1.</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >x = </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">;</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">%% Section 2.</span></span></div><div  class = 'S12'></div><div  class = 'S12'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >y = f(x);</span></span></div></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>The two consecutive percent signs </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>%%</span><span> tells MATLAB at which line a new section begins. In a Live Script, you can do this via the toolbar or by </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>Ctrl+Alt+Enter</span><span>. </span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>Arranging your sections according to the parts of a homework for you, should make quite a lot of sense. Having your sections correspond to the smaller sub(sub)-problems that you want to solve will help you diagnose which section is doing well/bad in what way, because you will be able to </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>run your sections in whichever order you like (i.e. non-sequentially)</span><span>. </span><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Beware</span><span>: This is a blessing as well as a curse. Again, you risk carrying over variables from one section to the other, which may scramble with your program. As long as you are careful and </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>clearvars</span><span> whenever needed, it is a powerful tool.</span></div><h3  class = 'S9' id = 'H_11193721' ><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>II.2. Explanatory &amp; Exploratory Code: Live Scripts</span></h3><div  class = 'S6'><span>As you write your code, you will often have to wrok through some trial and error and make some exploration and explanation. I find MATLAB Live Scripts help a great deal in doing so, i.e. in writing explorable &amp; self-explaining code. You can document what you find, do and obtain, in the same document as your code lives. If you have used Jupyter Notebooks or Google Colab for Python, this is a very good counterpart of them in MATLAB.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Text section.</span><span> The toolbar changes to the following look when you open a Live Scripts document.</span></div><div  class = 'S1'><img class = "imageNode" src = "data:image/jpeg;base64," width = "558" height = "86" alt = "toolbar_LS.jpg" style = "vertical-align: baseline; width: 558px; height: 86px;"></img></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>The Text section allows some simple manipulations to your text, such as adding titles and 3 levels of headers. You can have your text </span><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>bold</span><span>, </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>italic,</span><span> </span><span style=' text-decoration: underline;'>underlined</span><span> and </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>monospaced</span><span> (for in-line codes), aligned in various manners, in</span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span>bullet </span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>points</span></li></ul><div  class = 'S6'><span>or in </span></div><ol  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span>numbered</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>lists</span></li></ol><div  class = 'S6'><span>and even add some math if you know TeX markup:</span></div><div  class = 'S1'><span texencoding="P(A|B) = \frac{P(B|A)P(A)}{P(B)}" style="vertical-align:-15px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="146" height="34" /></span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>These help you write clean explanations for your code. You can add images and a table of contents based on your headers, and also choose where to view you output through the three options indicated below:</span></div><div  class = 'S1'><img class = "imageNode" src = "data:image/jpeg;base64," width = "537" height = "81" alt = "output.jpg" style = "vertical-align: baseline; width: 537px; height: 81px;"></img></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Code section.</span><span> The main use I make of the Code section is the controls and the section breaks. Take the following code piece, where I plot a single dot on the plane.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >indexVariable = </span></span><span>2.03</span><span style="white-space: pre"><span >;</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >y = </span></span><span>-6.24</span><span style="white-space: pre"><span >;</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >reflect = </span></span><span>true</span><span style="white-space: pre"><span >;</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >figure</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">if </span><span >reflect</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >        plot([0 -indexVariable], [0 -y], </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'bx-'</span><span >)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">else</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >        plot([0 indexVariable], [0 y], </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'bx-'</span><span >)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">end</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    </span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    title([</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'My vector X = (' </span><span >num2str(indexVariable, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'%.2f'</span><span >) </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">', ' </span><span >num2str(y, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'%.2f'</span><span >) </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">')'</span><span >])</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    xlim([-10 10]); ylim([-10 10]);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    xlabel(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'x'</span><span >); ylabel(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'y'</span><span >);</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><img src="data:image/png;base64," style="height: auto;"></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>You get to enter new values to my variables through a modular GUI interface that is very intuitive to use: It works the same way as if you have written that value there. This allows you to explore variables values within the bounds you specify, without typing and running and retyping and rerunning. Sectioning is quite important for controls: They determine what to compute (if you choose to) upon a change in their value.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Animations.</span><span> You may also choose to observe how certain values effect your outputs in motion. You can do this by repeatedly plotting on the same figure with some delay between the figures. Without the delay between the "frames", MATLAB will show only the end result. Here's an example:</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >animFig = figure; </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Create a figure in the variable animFig, so that I can refer to it by name</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">for </span><span >theta = (-2:0.01:2) * pi</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    figure(animFig) </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Current figure is animFig</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    plot([cos(theta) cos(theta*1.1) cos(theta*1.2) cos(theta)], </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >        [sin(theta) sin(theta*1.5) sin(theta*1.6) sin(theta)], </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >        </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'.-'</span><span >) </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Plot the plot</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    title(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Look at my moving triangle!'</span><span >)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    xlim([-1.5 1.5]); ylim([-1.5 1.5]);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    xlabel(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'x'</span><span >); ylabel(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'y'</span><span >);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    pause(0.001) </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Pause between frames</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">end</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><img src="data:image/png;base64," style="height: auto;"></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>After playing it once in a Live Script, MATLAB will allow you  </span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span>to play your animation in different speeds </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>without going through the same computations again</span><span>, </span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>rewind to specific points,</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>adjust playing speed, and </span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>save it in various video formats (.gif, .avi and .mp4).</span></li></ul><h3  class = 'S18' id = 'H_B919E053' ><span>II.3. Efficient &amp; Debugged Code</span></h3><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Vectorization.</span><span> MATLAB is a programming language that is optimized for operating on/with vector and matrix quantities, so whenever possible, you should vectorize your code. Again, a very simple example is the contrast between the following two codes, that apply the </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>sign()</span><span> function to a vector </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>x</span><span>.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>Not vectorized:</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >x = -2:2;</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >res = zeros(size(x)); </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Store the result here</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">for </span><span >k = 1:length(x)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    display([</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Doing loop ' </span><span >num2str(k) </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">' of ' </span><span >num2str(length(x))])</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    res(k) = sign(x(k)); </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Loop the loop</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">end</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsTextElement" uid="8EBC1268" data-scroll-top="null" data-scroll-left="null" data-testid="output_3" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="textElement eoOutputContent" data-width="1258" data-height="75" data-hashorizontaloverflow="false" style="max-height: 261px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">Doing loop 1 of 5
Doing loop 2 of 5
Doing loop 3 of 5
Doing loop 4 of 5
Doing loop 5 of 5</div></div></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S19'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >res</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsVariableMatrixElement" uid="164757A7" data-testid="output_4" data-width="1258" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="matrixElement veSpecifier eoOutputContent" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="veVariableName variableNameElement double" style="width: 1258px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="headerElementClickToInteract" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><span style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">res = </span><span class="veVariableValueSummary veMetaSummary" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(179, 179, 179); font-size: 12px;">1Ã—5</span></div></div><div class="valueContainer" data-layout="{&quot;columnWidth&quot;:40,&quot;totalColumns&quot;:5,&quot;totalRows&quot;:1,&quot;charsPerColumn&quot;:6}" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="variableValue" style="width: 202px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">    -1    -1     0     1     1
</div><div class="horizontalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div><div class="verticalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>As opposed to, vectorized:</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >x = -2:2;</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >res = sign(x)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsVariableMatrixElement" uid="B462872F" data-testid="output_5" data-width="1258" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="matrixElement veSpecifier eoOutputContent" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="veVariableName variableNameElement double" style="width: 1258px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="headerElementClickToInteract" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><span style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">res = </span><span class="veVariableValueSummary veMetaSummary" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(179, 179, 179); font-size: 12px;">1Ã—5</span></div></div><div class="valueContainer" data-layout="{&quot;columnWidth&quot;:40,&quot;totalColumns&quot;:5,&quot;totalRows&quot;:1,&quot;charsPerColumn&quot;:6}" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="variableValue" style="width: 202px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">    -1    -1     0     1     1
</div><div class="horizontalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div><div class="verticalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Same result, quicker code, no unnecessary loops. This can help immensely if you are working with large vectors &amp; matrices, and most MATLAB functions have some vector-matrix interpretation of their inputs built-in.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>Vectorization also applies to loops: Notice how I use a row vector </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>1:length(x)</span><span> in the loop above, and MATLAB goes over its entries. Well, not really. MATLAB goes over its </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>columns</span><span> as it progresses through the loops, meaning the loop variable is set to the columns of the index vector. A very simple example is the following:</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >indexVector = magic(3) </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Magic matrix generator in MATLAB,</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsVariableMatrixElement" uid="485659B5" data-testid="output_6" data-width="1258" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="matrixElement veSpecifier eoOutputContent" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="veVariableName variableNameElement double" style="width: 1258px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="headerElementClickToInteract" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><span style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">indexVector = </span><span class="veVariableValueSummary veMetaSummary" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(179, 179, 179); font-size: 12px;">3Ã—3</span></div></div><div class="valueContainer" data-layout="{&quot;columnWidth&quot;:40,&quot;totalColumns&quot;:3,&quot;totalRows&quot;:3,&quot;charsPerColumn&quot;:6}" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="variableValue" style="width: 122px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">     8     1     6
     3     5     7
     4     9     2
</div><div class="horizontalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div><div class="verticalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S20'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">for </span><span >indexVariable = indexVector</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    display(indexVariable)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">end</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsVariableMatrixElement" uid="1C131237" data-testid="output_7" data-width="1258" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="matrixElement veSpecifier eoOutputContent" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64);
