font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><span style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">indexVariable = </span><span class="veVariableValueSummary veMetaSummary" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(179, 179, 179); font-size: 12px;">3Ã—1</span></div></div><div class="valueContainer" data-layout="{&quot;columnWidth&quot;:40,&quot;totalColumns&quot;:1,&quot;totalRows&quot;:3,&quot;charsPerColumn&quot;:6}" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="variableValue" style="width: 42px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">     8
     3
     4
</div><div class="horizontalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div><div class="verticalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div></div></div></div><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsVariableMatrixElement" uid="8E08F748" data-testid="output_8" data-width="1258" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="matrixElement veSpecifier eoOutputContent" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="veVariableName variableNameElement double" style="width: 1258px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="headerElementClickToInteract" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><span style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">indexVariable = </span><span class="veVariableValueSummary veMetaSummary" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(179, 179, 179); font-size: 12px;">3Ã—1</span></div></div><div class="valueContainer" data-layout="{&quot;columnWidth&quot;:40,&quot;totalColumns&quot;:1,&quot;totalRows&quot;:3,&quot;charsPerColumn&quot;:6}" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="variableValue" style="width: 42px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">     1
     5
     9
</div><div class="horizontalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div><div class="verticalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div></div></div></div><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsVariableMatrixElement" uid="C50AF523" data-testid="output_9" data-width="1258" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="matrixElement veSpecifier eoOutputContent" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="veVariableName variableNameElement double" style="width: 1258px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="headerElementClickToInteract" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><span style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">indexVariable = </span><span class="veVariableValueSummary veMetaSummary" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(179, 179, 179); font-size: 12px;">3Ã—1</span></div></div><div class="valueContainer" data-layout="{&quot;columnWidth&quot;:40,&quot;totalColumns&quot;:1,&quot;totalRows&quot;:3,&quot;charsPerColumn&quot;:6}" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="variableValue" style="width: 42px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">     6
     7
     2
</div><div class="horizontalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div><div class="verticalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>If you have multiple parameters to go through, this can help you write concise and effective code easily. It's all up to your imagination.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>A final word about vectorization: Don't overuse or force it too much. If vectorization makes your code overcomplicated, avoiding it may be a good option. Your custom functions, in particular, may work well with scalars but throw a bunch of errors with vector inputs. Don't force yourself to vectorizing your custom function unless you a) can actually do it, or b) have computation time concerns.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Local &amp; Anonymous Functions.</span><span> While I am on the topic of custom functions: You don't always have to save your functions as separate files. If you want to declare functions just for the script you are working on (like in Python for example), you can do so by </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>writing them at the end of your file</span><span>. This is a little bit annoying, but it's still better than nothing (or having to save everything else as separate files). This works the same in regular </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>.m</span><span> scripts and in Live Scripts. You can see a custom iid. Bernoulli sampler at the end of this document, and here I am, calling it as usual:</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >Bernoulli()</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsVariableStringElement" uid="8391751F" data-testid="output_10" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="textElement eoOutputContent" data-width="1258" data-height="35" data-hashorizontaloverflow="false" style="max-height: 261px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><span class="variableNameElement" style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">ans = <span class="headerElement" style="white-space: pre; font-style: italic; color: rgb(179, 179, 179); font-size: 12px;">logical</span></span></div><div style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">   0
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>The only problem is that the help texts are not supported for these local functions:</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S10'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% help Bernoulli</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Another interesting way of declaring functions is via </span><a href = "https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/matlab_prog/anonymous-functions.html"><span>anonymous functions</span></a><span>. Anonymous functions are a good way of declaring auxiliary functions that help you a lot, but are not so essential that you would declare them as proper functions (think of lemmas versus theorems in mathematics). They are called exactly the same way as regular functions are. For example, below I write a simple function that counts how many times a value occurs in an array:</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >counter = @(vec, val) sum(1 - sign(vec-val).^2);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >counter(-2:5, 5)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>ans = 1</div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Anonymous functions are kept as variables in the environment, and are cleared with </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>clearvars</span><span>.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Debugging.</span><span> And now, the most important task of a coder, debugging.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>You will inevitably make mistakes when coding. MATLAB will throw errors, even if it doesn't the output of your code will not make sense sometimes. You will have to debug your code. Another good property about MATLAB is that it has a debugge rbuilt-in that works for both sciprts and Live Scripts and is very intuitive to use.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>As you can see, MATLAB automatically numbers your lines. What you may not have noticed is that those numbers are </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>clickable</span><span>. Clicking on one creates a </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>break point</span><span> at that line, making MATLAB stop execution just before that line. You can then </span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' font-style: italic;'>continue </span><span>until the end of execution,</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' font-style: italic;'>step</span><span> onto the next line, executing the marked one and stopping before the next,</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' font-style: italic;'>step in</span><span> to a function in the marked line, opening the function on it and continuing debugging there, and</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' font-style: italic;'>step out</span><span> if you have stepped in to a function, continuing until the completion of the current function and stopping right outside.</span></li></ul><div  class = 'S6'><span>When you are in debugging mode, you will also notice that the command window shows at the last line </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>K&gt;&gt;</span><span> instead of the regular </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>&gt;&gt;</span><span>. This indicates that the command window is now the </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>debug window</span><span>, where you can check and change the values of your variables.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>Now for a demonstration:</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >N = 10;</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >samples = Bernoulli(N);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >length(samples(samples == 1))</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>ans = 4</div></div></div></div><h3  class = 'S18' id = 'H_8D8D650D' ><span>II.4. Presentable Results</span></h3><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Figures.</span><span> This is arguable another prominently important topic in this guide, and it goes for regular scripts as well as Live Scripts. Most people don't really care how their figures look as long as they have the minimally required information. However, your figures are where you display your results in the most understandible way, and hence if your figures are ugly, or worse, unintelligible or lacking, the reader will think you don't have the required result. Having pretty figures is not that hard, and shows how seriously you take your work and professionalism. </span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>First of all, you should pick the correct plotting command for your figures. If you want to show</span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' font-style: italic;'>a continuous quantity,</span><span> use </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>plot()</span><span>.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' font-style: italic;'>a discrete sequence,</span><span> use </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>stem()</span><span>.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' font-style: italic;'>discrete data points without an inherent order on them (e.g. samples from a random variable),</span><span> use </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>scatter()</span><span>.</span></li></ul><div  class = 'S6'><span>These are rules of thumb that rarely accept exceptions, and when you do violate them, make sure you have a reason. In any case, make sure your </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>LineWidth</span><span> is at least 1 (MATLAB default is 0.5, I don't know why) to make the lines/markers visible. Enabling grid via </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>grid on</span><span> or </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>grid minor</span><span> is also good practice, as it allows an easier estimation of values presented in the figure. You must always be careful with the plot limits to make sure everything is clearly visible, and say, not overlapping with axis lines.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>If you want to plot more than one quantity on the same axis, you can write </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>hold on</span><span> or </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>hold('on')</span><span> on a separate line to tell MATLAB to keep holding on to the previous plots. When you have multiple plots on the same figure, always use the </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>legend()</span><span> command to tell the reader what line is what </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>on the figure</span><span>. Presenting this information in (say) the text </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>only</span><span> and forcing the reader to go back and forth between the figure and this explanation is not very nice.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>Label your axes whenever suitable, meaningful text and don't assume the reader will understand what the units are. Such clarifications are, at the very least, kind to the reader as it helps them understand, if not even mandatory. Similarly, always put a title to your figures. Your figures should almost be </span><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>stand-alone, self-explanatory pieces of information, packed with the minimally necessary amount of information to explain themselves</span><span>. In both of these cases, using </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>variable dependent titles/axis labels</span><span> is always handy. Convert your variables to a character array and append this string to a suitable position in your text.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>I realize I said a lot and showed very little, so let me give an illustrative example now regarding these. In the following, I calculate the probability that a sample from the standard Gaussian will fall within the </span><span texencoding="1 \sigma" style="vertical-align:-5px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="18.5" height="17.5" /></span><span> interval around the mean (don't worry if this doesn't make sense yet).</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >P_1sigmaRange_analytical = normcdf(1) - normcdf(-1);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >N_samples = </span></span><span>150</span><span style="white-space: pre"><span >; </span></span><span> </span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >samples = randn(N_samples, 1);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >samples_in = samples(abs(samples) &lt; 1);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >samples_out = samples(abs(samples) &gt;= 1);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >P_1sigmaRange_MC = length(samples_in) / length(samples);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S21'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >x = -5:0.01:5;</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Now that I have a  I make a bunch of results, I would like to present them in a figure. I start by creating a new figure.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S10'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >figure</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Hold on, as I want to show multiple plots.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S10'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >hold </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">on</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Turn the grid on.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S10'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >grid </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">on</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>I want to plot a continuous quantity, so I use </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>plot()</span><span>.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S10'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >plot(x, normpdf(x), LineWidth=1)</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Here I plot two different kinds of samples from the Gaussian random variable: Accepted and rejected. I display all of them as crosses (</span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>'x'</span><span>) and the accepted ones are in green whereas the rejected ones are red. So, to show the accepted ones as green crosses, I give </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>'gx'</span><span> as an argument, and similarly </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>'rx'</span><span> for the red crosses. Read the documentation for more information regarding marker/line specifications.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >scatter(samples_in, zeros(size(samples_in)), </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'gx'</span><span >) </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Presenting accepted samples in green, use scatter()</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >scatter(samples_out, zeros(size(samples_out)), </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'rx'</span><span >) </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Presenting rejected samples in red, use scatter()</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >legend(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'$\mathcal{N}(x\,; 0, 1)$'</span><span >, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Accepted'</span><span >, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Rejected'</span><span >, </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S21'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    Interpreter=</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'latex'</span><span >, Location=</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'best'</span><span >) </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Insert a legend to show what is what.</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>I want to have two lines as a title. To so do, I input to </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>title</span><span> a </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>cell array of string arrays</span><span>. The cell array is bounded by curly braces </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>{}</span><span>, and every cell entry is displayed on a separate line. For each line, I create a character array surrounded by </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>[]</span><span>, which serves to append the variable quantities to the text and create a single character array. I use </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>num2str()</span><span> with the second argument </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>'%.5f'</span><span> to indicate I want to show 5 digits after the decimal point.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >title({[</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Analytical probability: ' </span><span >num2str(P_1sigmaRange_analytical, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'%.5f'</span><span >)], </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);"> </span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S21'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >       [</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Monte Carlo estimate: ' </span><span >num2str(P_1sigmaRange_MC, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'%.5f'</span><span >) </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">' ($N = $' </span><span >num2str(N_samples) </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">')'</span><span >]})</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>I use </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>xticks()</span><span> to indicate, where within the bounds of the figure I want to add ticks to the x-axis. This line of code will put a tick to every integer from -5 upto 5 including. Note that I can give any numerical array, and it will only put ticks at those values as long as they are withing the axis limits.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S10'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >xticks(-5:1:5)</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>I bound my y-axis between -0.1 and 0.5 so that the samples I am taking and the continuous quantity are more visible.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >ylim([-0.1 0.5])</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><img src="data:image/png;base64," style="height: auto;"></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>A couple of concluding remarks: </span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span>Use logscale whenever appropriate. </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>loglog()</span><span> and </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>semilogx()</span><span> should be the ones most useful to you. They are themselves plotting functions like </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>plot()</span><span>, with the additional functionality of adjusting the axis scales to logarithmic. See their documentation for more information.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>You can use LaTeX math if you know how. I will not explain how to use LaTeX or TeX, but you can check </span><a href = "https://www.overleaf.com/learn/latex/Mathematical_expressions"><span>Overleaf</span></a><span> and </span><a href = "https://latex-tutorial.com"><span>LaTeX-Tutorial</span></a><span> to learn.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>autoArrangeFigures</span><span> should help you a lot when scripting (</span><a href = "https://www.mathworks.com/matlabcentral/fileexchange/48480-automatically-arrange-figure-windows"><span>Link</span></a><span>). It is a freely available code in the Mathworks community, and after downloading you should </span><a href = "https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/addpath.html"><span>add it to MATLAB path</span></a><span> to use it in any directory.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>If you are plotting quantities that are tightly related to one another that you cannot plot on the same figure, use </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>subplot()</span><span> </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>tiledlayout()</span><span>.</span></li></ul><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Startup File.</span><span> The following are simply some settings that I find useful. Their function is commented next to them.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >set(groot, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'defaultTextInterpreter'</span><span >, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'latex'</span><span >);       </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Change default text interpreters to latex</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >set(groot,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'defaultAxesTickLabelInterpreter'</span><span >,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'latex'</span><span >);  </span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >set(groot,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'defaulttextinterpreter'</span><span >,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'latex'</span><span >);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >set(groot,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'defaultLegendInterpreter'</span><span >,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'latex'</span><span >);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >set(groot,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'defaultStemLineWidth'</span><span >, 1);                </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Change default stem line width to 1</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >set(groot,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'defaultLineLineWidth'</span><span >, 1);                </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Change default plot line width to 1</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >set(groot,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'defaultScatterLineWidth'</span><span >, 1);             </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Change default scatter line width to 1</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >set(groot,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'defaultAxesXGrid'</span><span >,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'on'</span><span >);                  </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Turn x-axis grid on by default</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >set(groot,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'defaultAxesYGrid'</span><span >,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'on'</span><span >);                  </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Turn y-axis grid on by default</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >set(groot,</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'defaultfigureposition'</span><span >,[400 250 500 375]) </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Adjust default figure window position &amp; size</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S21'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >                                                     </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Window size default: 500 x 375 pixels</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>To have these setting run everytime MATLAB starts so you don't have to, you can create a </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>startup.m</span><span> file that MATLAB has in its Path. You can run the following command to access this </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>startup.m </span><span>file, or create it if it doesn't exist.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S10'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >edit(fullfile(userpath, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'startup.m'</span><span >))</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Submitting Homeworks &amp; Reports.</span><span> After seeing all the ways you can write a nice-looking report as a MATLAB Live Script with a </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>.mlx</span><span> extension, it also makes sense to export it in various formats so that it is computationally much lighter and portable. The most common option will be to export as a </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>.pdf</span><span> file. You can do so by going to "Export" on the toolbar and selecting "Export to PDF...". MATLAB then will run your code once from start to finish, create all the figures (animations are taken at their last frames) and replace controls with whatevery value they have at the time of export, and compile a report for you.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>One internal way of exporting is saving your </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>.mlx</span><span> Live Script as a regular </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>.m</span><span> MATLAB script file. When you do, your text will be converted to comment in a way that MATLAB can </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>publish</span><span> that </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>.m</span><span> file in various formats such as </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>.pdf</span><span>, much like exporting a Live Script file. If you do this, you will see that you can also write fancy-looking reports in a </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>.m</span><span> file, only this time you will be </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>coding</span><span> how your texts should look like and can see those modifications after you publish.</span></div><h2  class = 'S22' id = 'H_6539F7E4' ><span>III. MATLAB for Probability Computations</span></h2><div  class = 'S1'><span></span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>This section focuses on making computations regarding probabilities and random objects. It starts with a presentation of the basic functions and moves on with a brief interlude on handling continuous quantities. It will contain in the future a section about Monte Carlo simulations as well.</span></div><h3  class = 'S9' id = 'H_A6A82728' ><span>III.1. Functions for Probability</span></h3><div  class = 'S6' id = 'H_F91235E1' ><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Sampling from common distributions. </span><span>Sampling is one of the most natural things you can do with a probabilistic object. There are a couple of default sampling functions which produce very common random variables, and then there are functions for sampling from custom random distributions that you create.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>The most basic three random samplers are</span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span texencoding="U(0,1)" style="vertical-align:-5px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="46.5" height="17.5" /></span><span>, continuous uniform distribution between 0 and 1:</span></li></ul><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >uniformSample = rand()</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>uniformSample = 0.0965</div></div></div></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span texencoding="\mathcal{N}(0\,, 1)" style="vertical-align:-5px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="52.5" height="17.5" /></span><span>, standard Gaussian with zero mean and unit variance:</span></li></ul><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >stdGaussianSample = randn()</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>stdGaussianSample = -1.1201</div></div></div></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span>Random integer from 1 upto N, all equally likely:</span></li></ul><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >integerSample = randi(10)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>integerSample = 10</div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>A way of creating your own finite random objects is via the </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>randsample()</span><span> function. This allows you to sample from a vector (or matrix) with customizable weights that are automatically normalized to 1 (equal weights by default), with or without replacement. You are essentially specifying a probabilit space, with the sample space as a vector (or matrix) and probabilities.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >customSamples = randsample(1:10, 3, true, 1./(1:10))</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsVariableMatrixElement" uid="2BE7E296" data-testid="output_17" data-width="1258" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="matrixElement veSpecifier eoOutputContent" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="veVariableName variableNameElement double" style="width: 1258px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="headerElementClickToInteract" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><span style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">customSamples = </span><span class="veVariableValueSummary veMetaSummary" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(179, 179, 179); font-size: 12px;">1Ã—3</span></div></div><div class="valueContainer" data-layout="{&quot;columnWidth&quot;:40,&quot;totalColumns&quot;:3,&quot;totalRows&quot;:1,&quot;charsPerColumn&quot;:6}" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="variableValue" style="width: 122px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">     9     3     1
</div><div class="horizontalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div><div class="verticalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S6' id = 'H_6136C82B' ><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Evaluating PDFs &amp; CDFs.</span><span> There are not that many common pdfs or cdfs that are built-in as stand-alone functions in MATLAB as far as I know. The most commonly used one in my experience is the one belonging to Gaussian distribution: </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>normpdf()</span><span> and </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>normcdf()</span><span>.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >x = -5:0.01:5;</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >tiledlayout(2,1)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >nexttile</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >plot(x, normpdf(x))</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >title(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'PDF $f_X(x)$'</span><span >)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >ylim([-0.1 0.5])</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >nexttile</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >plot(x, normcdf(x))</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >title(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'CDF $F_X(x)$'</span><span >)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >ylim([0 1.1])</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >sgtitle(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Standard Gaussian $\mathcal{N}(0, 1)$'</span><span >, Interpreter=</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'latex'</span><span >) </span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><img src="data:image/png;base64," style="height: auto;"></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Alternative functions for the CDF of the standard Gaussian are </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>erf()</span><span> and </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>erfc()</span><span>, short for error function. You can refer to their documentation to see how they differ from </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>normcdf()</span><span>.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Random Seed.</span><span> Even though our computers are quite powerful devices, they cannot produce </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>truly</span><span> random objects. We must make do with </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>pseudorandom</span><span> objects which are as close as possible to true randomness using various algorithms, which are tested according to "how random" they are (In fact, generation of random samples in computers is a research area on its own.). MATLAB uses what is called a </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>seed</span><span> that acts like an integer key for the random number generation process. MATLAB sets this seed to </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>0</span><span> by default, and you can set it to any number you like via the </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>rng()</span><span> command (through which you can also change the sampling algorithm). You can see below that I set it to an arbitrary integer, and you will observe that consecutive calls to </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>rand()</span><span> produce the same result. </span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >rng(5670306)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >rand(1,5)'</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsVariableMatrixElement" uid="C664E7C4" data-testid="output_19" data-width="1258" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="matrixElement veSpecifier eoOutputContent" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="veVariableName variableNameElement double" style="width: 1258px; white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="headerElementClickToInteract" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><span style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">ans = </span><span class="veVariableValueSummary veMetaSummary" style="white-space: normal; font-style: normal; color: rgb(179, 179, 179); font-size: 12px;">5Ã—1</span></div></div><div class="valueContainer" data-layout="{&quot;columnWidth&quot;:66,&quot;totalColumns&quot;:1,&quot;totalRows&quot;:5,&quot;charsPerColumn&quot;:10}" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="variableValue" style="width: 68px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">    0.0707
    0.1991
    0.7447
    0.0207
    0.7129
</div><div class="horizontalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div><div class="verticalEllipsis hide" style="white-space: nowrap; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>This can be useful if you want your results to be </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>exactly</span><span> reproducible. But remember, you should always test it with other random seeds at least once to make sure your code works in general and not for that extremely specific/magical set of generated numbers by the seed you provide.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Recovering Distributions.</span><span> Histograms are a very useful tool in summarizing data or estimating the probabilty distribution from the samples of a random variables. They work by counting the number of data points within a certain partition of the underlying space, called bins. MATLAB's </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>histogram()</span><span> function is a very useful function that automates various choices that you have to make while constructing histograms. The </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>histogram()</span><span> can also be configured to estimate distributions by setting the </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>normalization</span><span> property. Notice that </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>histogram()</span><span> is a </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>plotting function</span><span>, meaning it will create a figure whenever it is called.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >samples = randsample(1:10, 1000, true, 1./(1:10));</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >figure</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >sampleHistogram = histogram(samples, </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    Normalization=</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'count'</span><span >); </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% set to 'probability' or 'pdf'</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >title({[</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Histogram of samples from my custom random variable'</span><span >], </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    [</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'N = ' </span><span >num2str(length(samples)) </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">' samples'</span><span >]})</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><img src="data:image/png;base64," style="height: auto;"></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>The </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>histogram()</span><span> function also returns an object, which can be stored in a variable as I am doing above. The properties of this object can be quite useful.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >sampleHistogram</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsVariableStringElement scrollableOutput" uid="08153984" data-testid="output_21" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="textElement eoOutputContent" data-width="1258" data-height="210" data-hashorizontaloverflow="true" style="max-height: 261px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><span class="variableNameElement" style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">sampleHistogram = </span></div><div style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">  Histogram with properties:

             Data: [1 1 2 1 1 1 4 6 1 5 3 5 3 1 3 10 2 1 1 1 10 1 2 1 4 1 2 2 1 10 3 5 10 8 7 2 5 2 1 1 2 2 5 2 5 1 1 2 1 1 2 3 4 4 5 6 5 5 3 4 1 1 3 6 2 5 2 1 1 1 3 1 3 2 2 6 9 5 3 7 1 6 1 2 2 5 7 1 4 3 3 5 1 2 5 6 7 2 1 8 1 3 7 1 1 4 3 10 3 1 1 6 1 â€¦ ]
           Values: [338 157 112 77 65 75 53 47 44 32]
          NumBins: 10
         BinEdges: [0.5000 1.5000 2.5000 3.5000 4.5000 5.5000 6.5000 7.5000 8.5000 9.5000 10.5000]
         BinWidth: 1
        BinLimits: [0.5000 10.5000]
    Normalization: 'count'
        FaceColor: 'auto'
        EdgeColor: [0 0 0]

  Show all properties
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Making a Multifunctional Random Object. </span><span>A useful way of creating a random object that comes equipped with various tools to help you out is using the </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>makedist</span><span> function. </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>makedist</span><span> can generate a wide range of random variables, which are listed in its documentation. </span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >stdGaussian = makedist(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Normal'</span><span >, mu=0, sigma=1)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsVariableStringElement" uid="1874E25C" data-testid="output_22" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="textElement eoOutputContent" data-width="1258" data-height="94" data-hashorizontaloverflow="false" style="max-height: 261px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><span class="variableNameElement" style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">stdGaussian = </span></div><div style="white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">  NormalDistribution

  Normal distribution
       mu = 0
    sigma = 1
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Let's see what methods this new object has.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >methods(stdGaussian)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsTextElement" uid="86EF65BB" data-scroll-top="null" data-scroll-left="null" data-testid="output_23" style="width: 1288.03px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;"><div class="textElement eoOutputContent" data-width="1258" data-height="46" data-hashorizontaloverflow="false" style="max-height: 261px; white-space: pre; font-style: normal; color: rgb(64, 64, 64); font-size: 12px;">Methods for class prob.NormalDistribution:

cdf        gather     icdf       iqr        mean       median     negloglik  paramci    pdf        proflik    random     std        truncate   var        </div></div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>That's nice: I can evaluate its pdf and cdf, as well as observe its variance and mean. I can also sample from it using the </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>.random</span><span> method.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >sample = random(stdGaussian) </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% stdGaussian.random()</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>sample = -0.8898</div></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S19'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >pdf_of_sample = stdGaussian.pdf(sample)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>pdf_of_sample = 0.2685</div></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S19'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >cdf_of_sample = stdGaussian.cdf(sample)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>cdf_of_sample = 0.1868</div></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S19'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >stdGaussian.mean()</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>ans = 0</div></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S19'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >stdGaussian.var()</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>ans = 1</div></div></div></div><h3  class = 'S18' id = 'H_5B26B0B2' ><span>III.2. Handling Continuous Quantities</span></h3><div  class = 'S6' id = 'H_EFD9D7BA' ><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>The Simplest Function I Know. </span><span>Let's calculate the integral of </span><span texencoding="f(x) = x" style="vertical-align:-5px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="58.5" height="17.5" /></span><span>, the simplest function I know, from 0 to 1. The result should be </span><span texencoding="1/2" style="vertical-align:-5px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="25.5" height="17.5" /></span><span> from calculus and intuition.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >dx = 0.001; </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% I wonder why I did that...</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >x = 0:dx:1;</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >f_x = x;</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >integral_f = sum(f_x)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>integral_f = 500.5000</div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>What? This is huge! What's wrong with my calculation?</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>What about the derivative, that should be easy enough: 1.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >f_prime_x = diff(x); </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% diff() is the closest thing to differentiation you can find in MATLAB</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >                     </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Check the documentation for more info.</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >figure</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >plot(x(2:end), f_prime_x) </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% diff decreases the length of the vector by 1</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >ylim([0 max(f_prime_x)*2])</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >title([</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">"Derivative of $f(x) = x$"</span><span >; </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">"It should be $f'(x) =1$, but I wonder if it will be..."</span><span >])</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >xlabel(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'x'</span><span >)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><img src="data:image/png;base64," style="height: auto;"></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Why isn't this giving me 1?</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Solution to both. </span><span>MATLAB is discrete in nature, so handling "continuous operations" requires some attention. For the integration let's go back to the Riemann integral: We have</span></div><div  class = 'S1'><span texencoding="\int_A f(x) dx \approx \sum_{P_i \in \mathcal{P}} f(x^*_i) \Delta x_i \quad \text{where}\quad x^*_i \in P_i\,, \Delta x_i = |P_i|\,, \bigsqcup P_i = A" style="vertical-align:-22px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="412.5" height="43" /></span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>for some sufficiently fine partition of the integration region. We want to have the LHS, but must make do with the RHS: My integration is missing the </span><span texencoding="\Delta x" style="vertical-align:-5px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="21" height="17.5" /></span><span> term, so it's like I multiplied the actual approximation to the integral by </span><span texencoding="\frac{1}{\Delta x}" style="vertical-align:-15px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="21" height="34" /></span><span>, that's why I obtain approximately </span></div><div  class = 'S1'><span texencoding="\frac{1/2}{0.001}= 500" style="vertical-align:-15px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="78" height="34" /></span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>The same logic goes for differentiation as well. Let's go back to the limit definition: I want </span></div><div  class = 'S1'><span texencoding="f'(x_0) = \lim_{\Delta x \to 0} \frac{f(x_0 + \Delta x) - f(x_0)}{\Delta x}" style="vertical-align:-15px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="206" height="36.5" /></span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>but have to settle with a "finitely small" </span><span texencoding="\Delta x" style="vertical-align:-5px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="21" height="17.5" /></span><span> term that I </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>have to include</span><span>: </span></div><div  class = 'S1'><span texencoding="f'(x_0) \approx \frac{f(x_0 + \Delta x) - f(x_0)}{\Delta x}" style="vertical-align:-15px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="177" height="36" /></span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>So, let's correct my mistakes.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >integral = sum(f_x) * dx</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>integral = 0.5005</div></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S20'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >f_prime_x = diff(x) / dx;</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >figure</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >plot(x(2:end), f_prime_x)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >ylim([0 max(f_prime_x)*2])</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >title([</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">"Derivative of $f(x) = x$"</span><span >; </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">"Now it is $f'(x) = 1$, so everything is fine"</span><span >])</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >xlabel(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'x'</span><span >)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><img src="data:image/png;base64," style="height: auto;"></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>A good question to ask at this point is, how should one choose </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>dx</span><span>? Ideally, it should be as small as possible, but that may not be possible for several reasons:</span></div><ul  class = 'S7'><li  class = 'S8'><span>Having </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>dx</span><span> extremely small will result in </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>immense </span><span>vectors, and your computer (being finite) cannot be able to store such large data.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>Your computer also has finite precision, meaning it has a certain representative power restricting how large or small numbers it can operate with. It most likely cannot even create or has an appropriate representation for the real number </span><span texencoding="10^{-12345678123456879435135469879543682}" style="vertical-align:-5px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="200" height="20" /></span><span>.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>Even if you can create such large arrays and such small values, you may risk computational stability of your results.</span></li><li  class = 'S8'><span>Finally, even if you dodhge </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>all</span><span> of these problems, your computer can take an </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>amazingly</span><span> long time to finish computation.</span></li></ul><h3  class = 'S18' id = 'H_7CA6769B' ><span>III.3. Monte Carlo</span></h3><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Parameter estimation example: Success probability of a Bernoulli R.V.</span><span> You have seen in the class that you can estimate the probability of success of a Bernoulli random variable with a quite intuitive estimator: Get </span><span style="font-family: STIXGeneral, STIXGeneral-webfont, serif; font-style: italic; font-weight: 400; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">N</span><span> samples, sum them up, and divide by </span><span style="font-family: STIXGeneral, STIXGeneral-webfont, serif; font-style: italic; font-weight: 400; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">N</span><span>. Let's see this estimator in action.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>I start by taking my iid. Bernoulli samples.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >p = </span></span><span>0.42</span><span style="white-space: pre"><span >; </span></span><span> </span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >N = </span></span><span>2000</span><span style="white-space: pre"><span >;</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S21'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >data = randsample([0 1], N, true, [1-p p]);</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Now that I have my samples, I will plot the trajectory of estimation: I run my estimator with the first </span><span style="font-family: STIXGeneral, STIXGeneral-webfont, serif; font-style: italic; font-weight: 400; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">n</span><span> samples as </span><span style="font-family: STIXGeneral, STIXGeneral-webfont, serif; font-style: italic; font-weight: 400; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">n</span><span> varies from 1 to </span><span style="font-family: STIXGeneral, STIXGeneral-webfont, serif; font-style: italic; font-weight: 400; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">N</span><span>.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >p_est_ = zeros(size(data)); </span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">for </span><span >n = 1:N</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    </span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    p_est_(n) = sum(data(1:n)) / n; font-weight: bold;'>Probability estimation example: Confirming the Gaussian 1-</span><span style="font-family: STIXGeneral, STIXGeneral-webfont, serif; font-style: italic; font-weight: 400; color: standard Gaussian r.v. fall within the 1-</span><span style="font-family: STIXGeneral, STIXGeneral-webfont, serif; font-style: italic; font-weight: 400; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">Ïƒ</span><span> range.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S13'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >P_1sigmaRange_analytical = normcdf(1) - normcdf(-1)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>P_1sigmaRange_analytical = 0.6827</div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Let's check this result by sampling from the standard normal distribution:</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >N_samples = </span></span><span>28870</span><span style="white-space: pre"><span >; </span></span><span> </span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >samples_in = samples(abs(samples) &lt; 1);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >samples_out = samples(abs(samples) &gt;= 1);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >P_1sigmaRange_MC = length(samples_in) / length(samples)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>P_1sigmaRange_MC = pre"><span >x = -5:0.01:5;</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >figure</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >hold </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, >)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >legend(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'$\mathcal{N}(x\,; 0, style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'latex'</span><span >, Location=</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'best'</span><span >)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >title({[</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Analytical probability: ' </span><span >num2str(P_1sigmaRange_analytical, </span><span style="color: >       [</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Monte Carlo estimate: ' </span><span >num2str(P_1sigmaRange_MC, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'%.5f'</span><span >) </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">' ($N = $' </span><span >num2str(N_samples) </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">')'</span><span >]})</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >xticks(-5:1:5)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><img src="data:image/png;base64," style="height: auto;"></div></div></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Passing samples through their own CDF.</span><span> Suppose we take a sample </span><span texencoding="X \sim f_X(x)" style="vertical-align:-6px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="62.5" height="18.5" /></span><span> from a continuous random variable, where </span><span texencoding="f_X(x)" style="vertical-align:-6px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="33.5" height="18.5" /></span><span> denotes the (continuous) PDF and </span><span texencoding="F_X(x)" style="vertical-align:-6px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="38.5" height="18.5" /></span><span> denotes the CDF. Now, we know theoretically that if we pass the sample </span><span style="font-family: STIXGeneral, STIXGeneral-webfont, serif; font-style: italic; font-weight: 400; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">X</span><span> through its own CDF to obtain a new random variable </span><span texencoding="F_X(X)" style="vertical-align:-6px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="41.5" height="18.5" /></span><span>, this new random variable will be distributed uniformly between 0 and 1, i.e.</span></div><div  class = 'S1'><span texencoding="F_X(X) \sim U(0,1)" style="vertical-align:-6px"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="104" height="18.5" /></span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>Let's try to form some intuition around this interesting fact. First, let's confirm this interesting fact via Monte Carlo using an exponential distribution.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >N = </span></span><span>100000</span><span style="white-space: pre"><span >;</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >exp_rv = makedist(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Exponential'</span><span >, mu=1);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S21'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >samples = exp_rv.random(N,1);</span></span></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Visualize the PDF and the samples.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >x = 0:0.01:(ceil(max(samples)/2)*2); </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Make the grid adaptible to the samples I am taking</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >figure</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >hold </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">on</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >plot(x, exp_rv.pdf(x))</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >plot(x, exp_rv.cdf(x))</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >scatter(samples, zeros(size(samples)) - max(exp_rv.pdf(x))*0.1, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'.'</span><span >)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >legend(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'$f_X(x)$'</span><span >, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'$F_X(x)$'</span><span >, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'$X \sim f_X$'</span><span >, </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    Location=</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'best'</span><span >, </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    Interpreter=</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'latex'</span><span >)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >title({</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Exponential Distribution with $\lambda = 1$'</span><span >, </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'$f_X(x) = \lambda e^{-\lambda x}$ for $x \geq 0$'</span><span >})</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >ylim([-0.2 1.2])</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >xlim([0 max(x)])</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><img src="data:image/png;base64," style="height: auto;"></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Now let's pass the samples through the CDF and make a histogram out of them. I set the </span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'>histogram()</span><span> to not counting but to estimating the PDF.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >figure</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >histogram(exp_rv.cdf(samples), </span><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 255);">...</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >    Normalization=</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">"pdf"</span><span >)</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >title({</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'Monte Carlo PDF estimate of $F_X(X)$'</span><span >, [</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'with $N = 10^' </span><span >num2str(log10(N)) </span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'$ samples'</span><span >]})</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >ylim([0 1.5])</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><img src="data:image/png;base64," style="height: auto;"></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>Now that we have confirmed the theoretical result by Monte Carlo, let's try to form some more intuition around this peculiar result.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>I want to take a look at the difference of samples in the first and last tenths of the samples, and the difference between them.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >sorted_samples = sort(samples);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S16'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >first_tenth = sorted_samples([1 (N/10)]);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >first_tenth_diff = diff(first_tenth)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>first_tenth_diff = 0.1032</div></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S20'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >last_tenth = sorted_samples([(N*9/10) N]);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >last_tenth_diff = diff(last_tenth)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>last_tenth_diff = 9.8739</div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>There is quite a difference. Now let's see what happens to this difference </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>after</span><span> I pass them through the CDF.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >first_tenth_afterCDF = exp_rv.cdf(first_tenth);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >first_tenth_afterCDF_diff = diff(first_tenth_afterCDF)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>first_tenth_afterCDF_diff = 0.0980</div></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S20'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >last_tenth_afterCDF = exp_rv.cdf(last_tenth);</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >last_tenth_afterCDF_diff = diff(last_tenth_afterCDF)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class='variableElement' style='font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Courier New", monospace; font-size: 12px; '>last_tenth_afterCDF_diff = 0.0998</div></div></div></div><div  class = 'S11'><span>There doesn't seem to be that much of a difference now! In fact, they are quite close. How is this the case?</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>Let's go back to the PDF and the CDF, and plot all of our results so far on a single plot. This will take some work, but it will be a good summary of our results.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >f = dense are indicated by a high PDF value, which in turn makes the CDF have a </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>higher slope</span><span> around that area. This higher slope means that the samples at </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>higher-density regions are separated more by the CDF.</span><span> Conversely, the regions where we have sparser samplesa are indicated by a low PDF value which in turn makes the CDF have a </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>lower slope</span><span> around that area. This lower slope means that the samples at lower</span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>-density regions are separated less by the CDF.</span><span> This readjustment of the distances between samples is done so perfectly by the CDF that the effects of dense sampling-more separation and sparse sampling-less separation cancel each other </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>perfectly,</span><span> yielding the uniform distribution between 0 and 1.</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span style=' font-weight: bold;'>Histogram Equalization. </span><span>What to make of the above result that we have just confirmed? One application of it in the image processing field is </span><span style=' font-style: italic;'>histogram equalization.</span><span> (The sample images and the functions imread()</span><span style=' font-family: monospace;'> and imshow()</span><span> require the </span><a href = "https://www.mathworks.com/products/image.html"><span>Image Processing Toolbox</span></a><span>.)</span></div><div  class = 'S6'><span>Suppose we have the following image.</span></div><div class="CodeBlock"><div class="inlineWrapper"><div  class = 'S15'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >originalImage = double(imread(</span><span style="color: rgb(160, 32, 240);">'pout.tif'</span><span >)); </span><span style="color: rgb(34, 139, 34);">% Read image, cast entries as double</span></span></div></div><div class="inlineWrapper outputs"><div  class = 'S17'><span style="white-space: pre"><span >originalImage(1:5, 1:5)</span></span></div><div  class = 'S14'><div class="inlineElement eoOutputWrapper embeddedOutputsVariableMatrixElement" uid="D9F2E9AE" data-testid="output_45" data-width="1258" style="width: 1288.03px;
